question: Was the agreement between Russia and Great Britain in 1907 inevitable?

content.source_1: [Paul M. Kennedy, The Rise of the Anglo-German Antagonism, 1860–1914 (Allen & Unwin, 1980) — Kennedy argues that Germany’s naval buildup and Weltpolitik created a systemic threat that pushed Britain to seek countervailing understandings with France (1904) and Russia (1907); the Anglo-Russian Convention thus emerged as a near-inevitable balance-of-power response to German pressure.]
content.source_2: [Keith Neilson, Britain and the Last Tsar: British Policy towards Russia 1894–1917 (Clarendon Press, 1995) — Neilson shows that exhaustion from the “Great Game” and the need to secure India made a settlement over Persia, Afghanistan, and Tibet highly attractive to London, while post-1905 weakness made St. Petersburg receptive; mutual imperial imperatives made the 1907 agreement a practical necessity.]
content.source_3: [T. G. Otte, The Foreign Office Mind: The Making of British Foreign Policy, 1865–1914 (Cambridge University Press, 2011) — Otte highlights the contingent, personality-driven nature of the 1907 deal, tracing how Edward Grey, Sir Arthur Nicolson, and A. P. Izvolsky steered fragile, often mistrustful negotiations; small missteps could have derailed talks, indicating the Convention was not “inevitable” but the product of specific actors and timing.]
content.source_4: [Christopher Clark, The Sleepwalkers: How Europe Went to War in 1914 (Harper, 2012) — Clark discusses Tsar Nicholas II’s 1905 Björkö agreement with Kaiser Wilhelm II, a serious attempt at Russo‑German alignment later undone in St. Petersburg; the plausibility of this alternative path undermines claims that an Anglo‑Russian accord in 1907 was foreordained.]
content.source_5: [Aaron L. Friedberg, The Weary Titan: Britain and the Experience of Relative Decline, 1895–1905 (Princeton University Press, 1988) — Friedberg argues Britain’s fiscal strain and strategic overstretch drove a policy of diplomatic “economy of force”; the Anglo‑Russian settlement was a cost‑saving way to stabilize Britain’s vulnerable imperial frontiers, making rapprochement with Russia a near-inescapable choice from a budgetary standpoint.]
content.source_6: [Zara Steiner and Keith Neilson, Britain and the Origins of the First World War (2nd ed., Palgrave, 2003) — Steiner and Neilson stress the Convention’s narrow, issue‑specific character (partitioning spheres in Persia, recognizing Britain in Afghanistan, and limiting action in Tibet), and the persistence of mutual suspicions; because it was a limited colonial arrangement rather than a binding alliance, its timing and form were contingent rather than inevitable.]
